Description: Cylinder jar of dull red pottery: with the remains of a pale cream slip. The jar has an external roll-rim, part of which is missing, and an incised line of decoration around the neck. On the side of the jar is an inscription in black ink.
Curator's comments: The inscription mentions ‘accounts from Upper Egypt’ in addition to the name of Sekhen/Ka, a Predynastic king who ruled over Upper Egypt just before the first unification of Egypt’s regions into one state. It is the oldest Egyptian inscription in the British Museum. The correct reading of this king's name is debated. This jar is one of a number of inscriptions on vessels which bear a similar serekh with the 'ka' arms inside. Some are written with the upright 'ka' sign, whilst others bear an upside-down version, interpreted as 'sekhen' ('to embrace'). Published in: Regulski, I. (ed.), 2022. Hieroglyphs: unlocking ancient Egypt, pp. 168-9

Bibliography: W. M. F. Petrie, 'Abydos' I (London, 1902), pl. II, 15; E. A. Wallis Budge 'A Guide to the Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Egyptian Rooms, and the Coptic Room' (London, 1922), 248 (right); Musée de la Vielle Charité, 'L’Egypte des millénaires obscurs' (Marseilles, 1990), pp. 92, 105 [416]; A. Roveri and F. Tiradritte [eds.], 'Kemet: Alle Sorgenti del Tempo' (Ravenna, 1998), p.37 [4].
Bibliographic references: Quirke 1990 / Who were the Pharaohs? A History of their Names with a List of Cartouches (p21)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2003, Apr-Oct, Graz, Eggenberg Palace, 'The Tower of Babel' 2022-2023 13 Oct-19 Feb, London, BM, Hieroglyphs: unlocking ancient Egypt
